meta-review.comment:
Hippo Penny - Here's my two cents on the latest turn-based tactics anthology, Songs of Conquest. I'm no critic, just a grog trying to have some fun and share my thoughts with fellow gamers.

First off, let me say that Songs of Conquest has heart. It's clear that the devs at Lavapotion are fans of the Heroes of Might and Magic series (who isn't?) and have put their own twist on things. The game's visuals are gorgeous, with a pixel art style that harkens back to the good ol' days.

Now, I know what you're thinking - is Songs of Conquest just another copycat trying to ride the coat-tails of the mighty Heroes series? Well, let me tell you, it's not just that. The devs have taken the core gameplay and added some personal touches that make it their own. It's modern, nostalgic, romantic, and exciting all at once.

But don't just take my word for it - check out what the critics are saying. Eurogamer gives it a solid 60, calling the battles "surprisingly punishing" but praising the game's ambition. God is a Geek loves it, giving it a score of 90 and calling it a "stand-out hit". And IGN Italia thinks it's "a respectful and heartfelt tribute" to Heroes of Might and Magic, with a score of 90 as well.

Of course, not everyone is singing the praises of Songs of Conquest. The Games Machine gives it an 85, saying that while it's a great game, the single-player campaign has a few flaws. And PC Games thinks it's a solid 80, praising its depth and scope but saying that the graphics aren't as flashy as some other games.

Me? I just think it's a darn good time. The gameplay is engaging, the characters are interesting, and there's plenty to keep you busy for hours on end. And hey, if it's not perfect, well, that's okay. It's an indie game, after all - we should be celebrating its imperfections.

So, what do I think? Well, let me just say that Songs of Conquest is a hippo-tastic good time. Go check it out, and see for yourself!
